page.title: 05INDUSTRY IN THE 19TH CENTURY
page.content: IN THE 19TH AND EARLY 20TH CENTURIES THE EAST MONKLANDS' FORTUNE LAY IN THE {RICH SEAMS OF COALS}E.G.HUMPH COAL FOR DOMESTIC USE AND THE MAKING OF BRICKS, MUSSELBAND AND PYATSHAW COALS FOR STEAM ENGINES AND MOST IMPORTANTLY, SPLINT COAL FOR USE IN THE IRON AND STEEL INDUSTRY. WITH THE EVER-INCREASING DEMAND FOR COAL AS THE INDUSTRIAL REVOLUTION TOOK OFF, THE EAST MONKLANDS GREW AND PROSPERED. BY THE 1830'S THERE WERE OVER 100 MINES IN THE AREA AT RAWYARDS, AIRDRIEHILL, BALLOCHNEY, WHITERIGG, DARNGAVIL AND STANRIGG, ETC. MANY SMALL VILLAGES GREW UP AROUND SOME OF THE LARGER MINES - SOME FROM EXISTING HAMLETS, OTHERS BUILT BY THE COALMASTERS NEAR THE PITHEAD.
